channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2019 The New York Times Company

item.title: Our Dreams of Peace: Envisioning an End to War in Afghanistan
item.media:description: Dozens of men marched for peace through southern Afghanistan in June, calling for an end to decades of relentless conflict.
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.description: Two New York Times reporters from Afghanistan find themselves suddenly dreaming of what they will do if peace comes — as are their friends, and even some Taliban.
item.dc:creator: FAHIM ABED and FATIMA FAIZI

item.title: Facing Big Brexit Votes, Theresa May Promises to Reopen Pact With E.U.
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May pledged to reopen the withdrawal agreement with the E.U., in a bid to win over hard-line Brexiters. But the move risks infuriating European officials.
item.description: The British prime minister took a step that is likely to complicate relations with frustrated officials in Brussels.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Five Arrested After Brazil Dam Collapse That Killed Dozens
item.media:description: Firefighters recovering a body on Monday after a mining dam collapse last week in southeastern Brazil.
item.description: Those arrested were directly involved in and responsible for the mining enterprise and its licensing, as well as in recent testing that found the dam to be stable.
item.dc:creator: MANUELA ANDREONI and SHASTA DARLINGTON

item.title: Pakistani Woman Accused of Blasphemy Will Remain Free, Supreme Court Rules
item.media:description: Soldiers outside the Supreme Court building in Islamabad, Pakistan, on Tuesday. The court’s acquittal of Asia Bibi on blasphemy charges in October led to violent protests.
item.description: A three-member panel dismissed a challenge to the top court’s October decision to free Asia Bibi, a Christian farmworker who had spent eight years on death row.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Bruce McArthur, Toronto Landscaper, Pleads Guilty in Murders That Shook City’s Gay Community
item.media:description: Bruce McArthur, a 67-year-old freelance landscaper, now a convicted serial killer.
item.description: In a case that opened a rift between Toronto’s gay community and its police, a landscaper has pleaded guilty to eight murders in the city’s Gay Village.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Huawei and China Have Limited Ways to Answer U.S. Charges
item.media:description: Wilbur Ross, the United States secretary of commerce, speaking on Monday about charges of bank fraud and stealing trade secrets against Huawei of China.
item.description: Slowing growth and the trade war could restrict Beijing’s ability to get tough. Huawei has shuffled its Washington staff, apparently seeking a reset in relations.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR and RAYMOND ZHONG

item.title: News Analysis: With U.S. and Taliban in Talks, Afghans Fear They Could End Up Trampled
item.media:description: President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan speaking to the media this month in Kabul, after registering as a candidate for the coming presidential election.
item.description: There are concerns in Afghanistan’s government that the Americans could be headed for a separate deal with the Taliban, if that is what it takes to get their troops out.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: ‘World’s Loneliest Duck’ Dies on Tiny Pacific Island That Loved Him
item.media:description: Trevor in a photo from last year, when he was the entire duck population of the Pacific island of Niue.
item.media:credit: Rae Finlay, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: His nickname was a little off, since Trevor, the only duck on the island of Niue, was beloved by its 1,600 residents. They mourned after he was killed by a stray dog.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR

item.title: The U.A.E. Handed Out Gender Equality Awards. All Went to Men.
item.media:description: The United Arab Emirates’ minister of interior, Sheikh Saif bin Zayed Al-Nahyan, in 2017. He was awarded with a prize for best personality supporting gender balance.
item.media:credit: Stephane De Sakuntin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The awards honored Emirati efforts to promote gender equality, but the visual impression created by the announcement prompted a wave of ridicule online.
item.dc:creator: ILIANA MAGRA

item.title: Palestinian Government Resigns, With No Clear Replacement
item.description: The move reflects the failure of efforts to reunite the West Bank, where the government is based, and the Gaza Strip, controlled by the militant group Hamas.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Germany Proposes to Ease, Not End, Nazi-Era Abortion Law
item.media:description: Activists gathered in Berlin last week to demand the abolishment of a law known as Paragraph 219a, which makes advertisement for abortion services in Germany illegal.
item.description: A compromise in Germany would make information on abortion providers publicly available, but women’s rights advocates say it does not go far enough.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: China’s Coal Plants Haven’t Cut Methane Emissions as Required, Study Finds
item.media:description: A coal-fired power plant in Zouping, Shandong Province, China.
item.media:credit: Giulia Marchi for The New York Times
item.description: China in 2010 promised to curb methane emissions. In the first five years, it failed to keep its promise, according to new research based on satellite data.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Theresa May Wants the E.U. to Renegotiate Brexit. Will It?
item.media:description: Protesters opposing and demanding Brexit near Parliament in London in Tuesday.
item.description: Brussels has said many times that the “Irish backstop” cannot and will not be renegotiated. But a paradox lurks at the heart of its position.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: How to Disable FaceTime to Avoid Eavesdropping Bug
item.media:description: A recently uncovered bug in Apple’s FaceTime app allowed users to eavesdrop on someone else without their knowledge. The company said it is working on a fix.
item.description: Apple has disabled Group FaceTime, the feature that enabled the eavesdropping, while it works on a fix. But for extra security, follow these steps.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW HAAG
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods

item.title: White House Memo: Why Did Soviets Invade Afghanistan? Documents Offer History Lesson for Trump
item.media:description: Soviet soldiers in January 1980 in Gardez, Afghanistan, a month after the Soviet Union invaded. A newly published cable suggests a reason for the invasion was a fear that Afghanistan might switch loyalties to the West.
item.description: President Trump claimed the Soviet Union went to war in 1979 to battle terrorists. But a newly published cable underscores Moscow’s fear that Afghanistan would switch loyalties to the West.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Venezuelan Opposition Leader Guaidó Controls U.S. Bank Accounts, State Dept. Says
item.media:description: The United States has recognized Juan Guaidó as the leader of Venezuela.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: The State Department’s decision to turn over assets and property to Juan Guaidó is part of a Trump Administration effort to oust President Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Kim Bok-dong, Wartime Sex Slave Who Sought Reparations for Koreans, Dies at 92
item.media:description: Mourning Ms. Kim in Seoul on Tuesday. Her funeral will be held on Friday. Organizers said the funeral procession would pass by the Japanese Embassy.
item.description: Ms. Kim, one of the thousands of women forced to work in Japanese brothels during World War II, was among the first to break decades of silence about their ordeal.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Data Breaches Dent Singapore’s Image as a Tech Innovator
item.media:description: Processing blood samples at a Singapore clinic in 2007. The Health Ministry said this month that confidential information from its H.I.V. Registry had been illegally disclosed online.
item.description: Experts say security concerns are a pitfall for countries that are pushing to make vast troves of data more accessible and centralized.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Huawei, Apple, Polar Vortex: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.media:description: An American military post in Nangarhar Province, Afghanistan, last year.
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS STANFORD

item.title: Brexit, Afghanistan, Robert Mueller: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.media:description: Pro- and anti-Brexit protesters mingled outside Parliament in London on Monday.
item.description: Let us help you start your day.
item.dc:creator: PENN BULLOCK

item.title: FaceTime Bug Lets iPhone Users Eavesdrop, in a Stumble for Apple
item.media:description: The FaceTime bug could also give a caller access to a live feed of the recipient’s camera.
item.description: A glitch in the video and audio calling app, which the company says it will fix, can turn the device into one perhaps better suited for espionage.
item.dc:creator: BRIAN X. CHEN
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods

item.title: Pope Calls Child Sex Abuse ‘a Human Problem,’ Tamping Down Summit Expectations
item.media:description: Pope Francis boarding a plane for departure from Panama City on Sunday. “We have to deflate expectations,” he said on the plane, “because the problem of abuse will continue, it is a human problem.”
item.description: Pope Francis said the meeting at the Vatican in February would impress on bishops the suffering of victims and help church leaders better follow procedures when an allegation is made.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Government Shutdown, Polar Vortex, Apple: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: REMY TUMIN and HIROKO MASUIKE

item.title: Cooper-Boles Amendment Challenges Theresa May’s Brexit Strategy
item.media:description: Yvette Cooper, center, a member of Britain’s Parliament, in London this month. She is proposing an amendment that could delay Brexit.
item.description: The Cooper-Boles amendment, on which lawmakers may vote on Tuesday, could delay Britain’s exit from the European Union.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: ‘All Options Are on the Table’ in Venezuela, Says Bolton
item.description: John R. Bolton, the national security adviser, indicated that President Trump was still not ruling out military intervention in his efforts to pressure Nicolás Maduro, the president of Venezuela, to step down. The Trump administration also announced new sanctions on Venezuela.

item.title: The Case of the Bumbling Spy: A Watchdog Group Gets Him on Camera
item.media:description: A visitor to New York who claimed to be an investor named Michel Lambert is actually Aharon Almog-Assoulin, a retired Israeli security official.
item.description: Citizen Lab has reported on surveillance software used to target dissidents around the world. Now it is being targeted by mysterious, if bumbling, spies.
item.dc:creator: RONEN BERGMAN and SCOTT SHANE

item.title: ISIS Bombing of Cathedral in Philippines Shows Group’s Reach Into Asia
item.media:description: The Roman Catholic cathedral on Jolo, on the island group of Mindanao, Philippines, on Monday, a day after two explosions tore through the cathedral.
item.description: A deadly church bombing in the Philippines suggests that the extremist group is still able to fan the flames of distant militant movements.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH and JASON GUTIERREZ
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Brexit, Singapore, Nissan: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.media:description: Anti-Brexit demonstrators outside Parliament on Monday.
item.description: Let us help you start your day.
item.dc:creator: ALISHA HARIDASANI GUPTA

item.title: ‘It Was Like a Turbine’: Havana Residents React to Deadly Tornado
item.description: “It took everything,” one Havana resident said after a tornado hit Cuba’s capital. Another described cars tumbling down streets and roofs falling off buildings.

item.title: Jamal Khashoggi Inquiry Expands, as U.N. Official Arrives in Turkey
item.description: The French human rights expert Agnès Callamard is expected to spend a week in the country, interviewing officials and Mr. Khashoggi’s fiancée, Hatice Cengiz.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Use of Force in France’s ‘Yellow Vest’ Protests Fuels Anger
item.media:description: Officers carrying rubber ball launchers during a demonstration in Paris this month. Anger at officers’ use of force has helped fuel the nationwide “Yellow Vest” movement.
item.description: Thousands have been injured, including dozens seriously hurt by rubber projectiles. Critics call the police reaction excessive, but officials say officers have performed well.
item.dc:creator: ELIAN PELTIER

item.title: Singapore Says Records for 14,200 H.I.V. Patients, Held by an American, Were Leaked
item.media:description: The Singaporean police notified the Health Ministry last week that confidential information from its H.I.V. Registry “may have been disclosed by an unauthorized person.”
item.description: The medical records were illegally disclosed online, the Ministry of Health said, in the second major breach of Singapore’s health records since July.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Pilot in Nepal Plane Crash Had an ‘Emotional Breakdown,’ Officials Say
item.description: A report found that the captain’s “moody and aggressive” behavior during the flight might have contributed to the crash last year, which killed 51 people.
item.dc:creator: BHADRA SHARMA

item.title: The Brexit Amendment Process That Could Reshape Britain’s Future
item.media:description: Brexit-related protests in London this month. Parliament is set to debate the prime minister’s proposed next steps as well as alternative plans put forward by other lawmakers.
item.description: British lawmakers are to vote on Tuesday on a series of changes in the prime minister’s plans for withdrawal from the European Union. Here’s what could happen.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN MUELLER

item.title: Tornado Strikes Havana, Killing at Least 3
item.media:description: The tornado killed three people and injured 174 others, the Cuban president said on Twitter.
item.description: Photographs posted on Twitter by Cuban news outlets and residents of the capital showed cars crushed by fallen lampposts and cars trapped in floodwaters.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Afghanistan, Howard Schultz, ‘Rent’: Your Monday Briefing
item.media:description: U.S. troops in Afghanistan in 2011. The war there is America’s longest.
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS STANFORD

item.title: U.S. and Taliban Agree in Principle to Peace Framework, Envoy Says
item.media:description: Afghan Army troops, left, and American soldiers attacking a Taliban firing position in 2013.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: The U.S. negotiator, Zalmay Khalilzad, says that finalizing a deal would hinge on a cease-fire and Taliban talks with Afghans, which they are discussing now.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Chinese Rights Lawyer Swept Up in Xi’s Crackdown Gets More Than 4 Years in Prison
item.media:description: Li Wenzu, wife of the rights lawyer Wang Quanzhang, wearing a sweater with her husband’s portrait and the words “Release Quanzhang” in Beijing on Monday.
item.description: Wang Quanzhang, an outspoken rights advocate, had been in custody since 2015 under President Xi Jinping’s campaign to obliterate threats to Communist Party control.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Abortion, Newly Legal in Ireland, Faces Old Roadblocks
item.media:description: “We’re back in hushed tones,” Erin Darcy, an abortion rights activist, said at her home near Galway, Ireland.
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.description: Women say the entire process is still hush-hush, given an emboldened anti-abortion movement and a continuing stigma that has left doctors slow to sign up for the service.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: A Thai Singer Wore a Swastika. Was It Prejudice or Ignorance?
item.media:description: The singer Pichayapa “Namsai” Natha, left, and her manager, Nataphol Pavaravadhan, met with the Israeli ambassador, Meir Shlomo, in Bangkok on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Embassy of Israel in Thailand, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The episode is one of several Nazi-related controversies to crop up in Asia, where Holocaust awareness is patchy, swastikas resemble an ancient symbol, and some see Hitler as a model of strength.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Roger Stone, Venezuela, Huawei: Your Monday Briefing
item.media:description: President Trump announcing the temporary end of the government shutdown on Friday.
item.description: Let us help you start your day.
item.dc:creator: PENN BULLOCK

item.title: As 2nd Brazil Dam Threatens to Collapse, Death Toll Rises to 58
item.media:description: Members of a rescue team on Sunday carrying a body recovered from the mud that flowed after a dam owned by the Brazilian mining company Vale collapsed.
item.description: Two days after a dam break left at least 58 dead, residents of Brumadinho are forced to evacuate again, while experts warn that the regulatory system is flawed.
item.dc:creator: MANUELA ANDREONI and SHASTA DARLINGTON

item.title: Canada Dispatch: ‘The Nation Has Stood Up’: Indigenous Clans in Canada Battle Pipeline Project
item.media:description: The Royal Canadian Mounted Police clearing a roadblock set up by a First Nations group in remote British Columbia.
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.description: On one side of a barricade in remote British Columbia, members of the Wet’suwet’en people hoped to stop a pipeline that would cross their traditional land. On the other side were heavily armed police.
item.dc:creator: AMBER BRACKEN

item.title: Duke University Apologizes Over Professor’s Email Asking Chinese Students to Speak English
item.media:description: A professor said in an email that two faculty members complained about students speaking Chinese “very loudly” in common areas on campus. Duke apologized and said it would investigate the email.
item.media:credit: Jeremy M. Lange for The New York Times
item.description: The university is conducting an internal review after a professor sent an email cautioning international students from speaking Chinese on campus.
item.dc:creator: SARAH MERVOSH

item.title: Afghan Women Fear Peace With Taliban May Mean War on Them
item.media:description: Afghan women lining up to vote in a parliamentary election in Herat Province in October.
item.description: The idea of an American troop withdrawal fills Afghan women with dread, as they see Westerners as their only protectors not just from the Taliban, but also the “Taliban mentality” among other men.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND, FATIMA FAIZI and FAHIM ABED
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: In Paris, ‘Red Scarves’ March to Counter Yellow Vest Protests
item.media:description: Counter-protesters marching in Paris on Sunday.
item.description: Thousands of protesters marched in the French capital to condemn the violence of the Yellow Vest movement. Some were wearing the red scarves as a symbol.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Hundreds Still Missing After Dam Collapse in Brazil
item.description: Before and after images show the damage caused by the collapse of a mining dam in Brumadinho, Brazil. At least 58 are dead and hundreds are still missing.

item.title: Another Side of #MeToo: Male Managers Fearful of Mentoring Women
item.media:description: Vice President Mike Pence has said he never dines alone with a woman other than his wife, a maxim that has become widely known as the Pence Rule.
item.description: At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, some male leaders said they were avoiding one-on-one time with junior female colleagues, a trend that could deprive women of valuable exposure.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD
